title.narrative: Strengthening Civil Societys Role in Peace

description.narrative: Strengthening civil societys role in the peace process in Myanmar

The project was directly related to the on-going national ceasefire negotiations and the upcoming political dialogue in Myanmar.
The ethnic armed conflict is considered to be the longest civil war in the world. Historically, civil society in Myanmar has been weakened. There is still insufficient capacity amongst civil society to take on the role of intermediaries in an effective way. The country is moving forward and ceasefire agreements are signed by stakeholders, however the armed conflict is still very much present in people's lives. Distrust in the peace process and the involved parties, and the lack of transparent and accountable governance structures are the main challenges in the peace building process.
Through the program, CSOs started an inclusive dialogue with a broad coalition of stakeholders. This was needed to reach a political settlement that includes political and economic power-sharing, and equal rights for ethnic groups. Civil society had a key role to play in building this coalition. CSOs have mediated between the various armed groups and increased awareness and knowledge among civil society on the armed conflict and its impact. They have also engaged local communities in the peace process and represented their voice. Civil society networks are essential for the achievement of 'bottom-up' social and political transition in Myanmar.

This project, which closed in February 2016, aimed to strengthen the capacity of 6 local civil society organizations (CSOs) to play a major role in the peace process of the conflict in Kayah. The CSOs have become effective intermediaries in the peace process, sharing information with communities and raising awareness. The CSOs also represented the voice of local communities.
